SMITE is an incredibly fun and addicting 3rd person MOBA that is perfect for those who are looking for a change from your typical MOBA. I joined in 2014 and still playing this game alot. It's really good and even more for people who like mythological and fantasy creatures like me. So give it a try if you don't know what the game is about. It's free and it won't hurt you to try it out.

In Smite there is currently  69 gods from different pantheons [www.smitegame.com]

Chinese, Egyptian, Greek, Roman, Hindu, Mayan, Norse and hopefully more in the future. This game is updated every 2 weeks with new content! (skins with gorgeous details for a MOBA, Amazing art for cards, alot of gems events and free gems every week and much more...). And every month there is a new god release with a gorgeous model and an interesting kit at your disposal.

There is also alot of different game modes, so the game almost never feel repetitive and boring.

reviewText:
SMITE is a fantastic game. It puts the MOBA genre into a 3rd-person perspective; that allows me to implement the aiming, timing and skills I've gained playing other games. The combat‚Äôs fast and highly addictive.

Compared with League of Legends and Dota 2, it relies less on builds and the minions/creeps, but doesn't remove those elements of strategy either. Rather than losing an integral part of what makes other MOBA games enjoyable and meaty, it replaces them with what gives games like FPS/3PS shooters depth. It panders to, and compliments a different style; thus gives a very different experience.

Minions aren't as strong or relevant late game as in Dota, but it feels right. You're playing the role of a god, and by the time you're at end-game, you'll have bigger threats to worry about-- the other gods. It's satisfying to build a tank that 5 enemy gods and a tower, all at once, can't easily kill. It's feels great to have your team expect you to clutch, but succumb to the pressure and miss all your shots. I love saving a teammate at the last moment by landing a perfectly aimed and timed kiss from Aphrodite.

It's about timing your attacks, weaving in and out of battle, aim and speed. Team fights are intense and replicate the rush you'd expect from a competitive shooter, all while respecting the governing outline of a MOBA game. That makes SMITE, a truly unique experience.

Most people who claim SMITE sucks"
date: play LoL or Dota. They see other games within the same genre as direct competition to the game they love. They don't care about enjoying games for what they offer; they compare and contrast simply to feel like they‚Äôre part of a team‚Äîfor the sake of ego. It‚Äôs as though they themselves had a hand in development
hoursPlayed: very proud.\n\nMost of them like to say SMITE‚Äôs not as deep. I argue the opposite. I feel where it lets go in micromanaging; it substitutes with a skill-oriented
voteText: high speed combat experience; that has depth and develops a skillset absent from other MOBAs. So it really comes down to misunderstanding the skills necessary in SMITE.\n\nI've been playing SMITE for probably a year now. I should have at least 300 hours

votesFunny: and If I want to play with them
commentsCount: I‚Äôm going to have to play their favorite MOBA.\n\nIt would enhance my experience to play with them on SMITE

reviewText:
I think it's about time I finally review this game.

I've had a history with this game. I've played this game since Isis was released, which was over 2 years ago. I remember that I was a HUGE fan of the old Sun Wukong (Hun Batz nowadays) and enjoyed the game, although I never got hooked into it. I eventually just stopped playing and went to get addicted to other games, namely Team Fortress 2. Fast foward to 2015, where SMITE is finally released on Steam. I was very curious to give this another try, so I did. Now, before I continue, I have something to say. All of my good friends know this fact well, and I HEAVILY emphasize this:

I hate MOBA games.

Long story with that, but I just never liked them, besides Awesomenauts. I downloaded SMITE and gave it a second chance, figuring it might be pretty cool now. Okay, this is the part where you look at the number of hours I have in the game. Just take a nice, solid look at it. To the review!

Graphics
MOBAs aren't known to have god-tier graphics (heh) and SMITE is no exception. The game is just... eh. It's sort of bland, but at the same time it actually looks really nice in some places, like Siege and Conquest. Not much to say here, but this is not a game for the photographers out there like myself.

Gameplay
The big question to this is, Is SMITE a good enough MOBA to compare with LoL and DOTA?" The answer to that question is
recommended: yes! I find it much better to BE the character your playing as
hoursPlayed: rather than telling them what to do. It's what makes SMITE stand out from the rest of the crowd
voteText: and it shines brightly in this way. I don't want to start a flame war
helpfulPercent: but although it is very simple to understand
votesHelpful: the game is much more difficult to master because of the fact you have to actually LAND your shots. No more "clicky-clicky here's the part where 3 champions die" or whatever. Your abilities matter
votesTotal: and missing one could change the course of a game. Plus
votesFunny: of course
commentsCount: teamwork is important in Conquest
column16: and I haven't actually encountered many "OP" gods
column17: if any at all. Some items are clearly better than others *cough* bluestone pendant *cough* *cough* but most aren't too severe. Overall
column18:
SMITE delivers with the gameplay by miles.

Story
Just like whether or not Set will be added to the game

there is no known story. This will not be counted towards the final score.

Audio
The audio isn't all that special

but the some of the voice packs you can purchase for gods are actually really funny. Some of the writing is extremely clever and gives the game a LOT of personality.

Replayability
Compared to DOTA and LoL
column21: this game is much easier to pick up and play
column22: although still being a very competitive game. The community
column24: is much easier to deal with and far friendlier than those other toxic wastes of "communities." The gameplay

Verdict
In the end

reviewText:
PSA: Don't use an older overclocked cpu with Windows 8-10, it'll cause bugs in SMITE that'll trigger a permanent ban that will not be lifted.

This is my recent experience with the game. It's not meant to jab at the game itself, but the problems I've dealt with the product and its company. My hours are not accurate and I've played before it was on Steam.

This game has a bug with WIndows 8/8.1/10 where using an older generation CPU like the Lynnfield/Bloomfield processors overclocked (via the FSB, not multiplier) causes your system (Windows TIme) clock to run faster. This in turn also causes syncing issues with games of the Unreal Engine for some bizarre reason.

Games like Rocket League will cause you to d/c from the match. Games like SMITE that also use the same engine? They will cause you to move faster in game, or just outright give you 300-400ms. I got the latter, thankfully not the former or at least that's what I think, rubberbanded a lot, too. I reported this on their feedback page, unaware of the Windows 8/8.1/10 problem because I've been on Windows 7 until three weeks ago.

Nonetheless, this problem flags their anticheat, permanently banning you. If you get banned by this system, there's no way out, they don't care, unless you take it to the subreddit and call them out. Unfortunately, /r/Smite now has rules against this type of behavior, so have fun trying to get things addressed with Hirez support. I was banned. My friend is friends with HirezTom and he told him to tell me to send in a support ticket and it'll be resolved, no problem. I was relieved, I thought to myself, hey if this guy is nice about it, I'm sure the support team will also care and try to help me figure out what went wrong.

No. That's not what happened at all. I left a ticket, sent in various screenshots, unaware of this cpu bug. I verified and proven my Windows 10 install and everything on my PC was fresh, brand new, basically. This leads to me my first problem, I was given a eula copypasta" saying I used software to modify the game
date: indicating they didn't even bother to read my ticket.\n\nTheir support team will give you a copypasta "no" response
hoursPlayed: there's a thread with over 5 pages about the Overclock ban and how they all got the same automated response.\n\nThey won't talk to you
voteText: they treat you as a robot. They will close your ticket if you re-open it
helpfulPercent: and if you're persistent about wanting to talk to an actual person
votesHelpful: they'll ban your customer support account. It's a known problem with HiRez and I've supported them since the Global Agenda days because I never ran into these issues until I was forced to install Windows 10. I've played this game before playing through the launcher on Steam
votesTotal:
hence my low hours.

The game has gone through subtle changes over the years and I'm sure it'll still be popular. But obviously I can't recommend the game due to their subpar customer support that makes even Steam Support look like a top-notch customer support service.

It's a slap in the face to not communicate with dissatisfied customers and players of their product.

If I ever do pick up this game again or any of their games
votesFunny: I probably won't be spending money on any of their microtransactions. I bought stuff like skins because they were nice and it supports the company. I can't support a company I wanted to work for in the past because of how poorly they treated their customers.\n\nIf you have fun in this game

reviewText:
Note: I have 1000+ hours pre-steam.

If you've got the stomach for objective based multiplayer deathmatch, you should give this a try. For those familiar with MOBAs the structure of the game will be familiar. But for those that don't know, two teams of 5 try to push across a field to each others base, breaking defensive towers on the way, trying to stay alive and make the enemy die. There are other game modes but they mostly sit as variations on this theme.

What really sets SMITE apart is the way you control your hero. Rather than the awkward click to move and attack system of other MOBAs you move with WASD, and aim your attacks as you would in a shooter, with your mouse. In SMITE 99% of the attacks are skillshots. Dodging is a real tactic, and you do it by moving, not submitting a request to move via your mouse cursor. There are more than enough characters for you to find several you're excited about playing. The game comes to you in layers, as you become comfortable moving around, aiming, and dodging, you begin to see new opportunities to improve. Whether it's making a smart predictive shot through the wall, or suckering an opponent into attacking you when you have a hidden teamate nearby, you'll start to get hype on smart plays, and you'll feel the pressure of avoiding your opponent's in turn. Integration with curse voice is nice, and even if you don't feel like jumping on the mic, there are shortcut keys to make tons of useful communications. This takes some getting used to but you get fast on it.

The game is at it's best in Conquest(the primary mode), but sadly is plagued by the same problem every other MOBA has. There is one map, with one set of objectives. As far as I know Heroes of the Storm is the only game that has bothered offering some variety in the 5v5 queue. I'd like to see them slow down the release of new heroes a bit, and offer some interesting twists in the 5v5 matches.

There is absolutely no pay to win system, and while there's always a lingering balance issue here or there, it's usually not really gamebreaking, and rarely will be enough to stop the better player from winning. You can unlock all the gods through gameplay, and color swaps for thier default skins. That said, the ultimate god pack, unlocks all the gods, current and future, and I strongly recommend it. It's a good way to support the game and it gives you all the toys to play with in your matches. I paid $40 for it, and I ain't even mad. The rest of the cash shop is premium skins and other vanity items, my only gripe in the cash shop are the chests". These are virtual lottery tickets

A great alternative to the isometric style MOBAs. Great selection of Gods to choose from from the Hindu, Chinese, Norse, Mayan, Egyptian‚Äé, Roman and Greek pantheons, fair store prices (you can pay $30/¬£21 to unlock all current and future Gods(EDIT: Currently ¬£14.06 on Steam!)) with plenty of ways to earn gems for premium skins and deep and rewarding gameplay that is quite unique to the genre. reviewText:
If you think I missed something in my review feel free to tell me

Smite
Smite is my most played game, and trust me there is a reason for that. I will add a TL; DR at the end.

Gameplay
Smite is a MOBA that has been around for a couple years and has gained some nice popularity. The main thing that people like about smite, that it offers different than other MOBA games such as Dota or League of Legends is that it is in third person. This means you actually have to aim your basic attacks and abilities and you much more control utilized the WASD keys for movement.

The game itself offers a total of 7 different gamemodes, not including ranked, that you can play. The gamemodes include a 5v5 Arena, 3v3 Joust, 5v5 Conquest, 5v5 Clash, 4v4 Siege, 5v5 Assault and a gamemode of the day that always offers something different. The matchmaking is on a decent timer usually taking anywhere from 20 seconds to 3 or 4 minutes to find a match (usually, ranked can easily take longer).

In smite there are gods from a handful of pantheons actually to be exact 76 gods in the game as of now, each with varying usefulness depending on the situation. An amazing thing which personally all MOBA games *cough* League *cough* should do is have an ultimate pack like Smite. This ultimate packs includes every single god in Smite, present and future, for one purchase and it is honestly one of the greatest things available. Smite also offers its premium currency as a daily reward and has a good community. By a good community I mean that this game has a good community, not a perfect community, don't get me wrong you WILL run into toxic individuals. I personally play joust and the people I find are kind and helpful and usually understanding, but what people need to understand is the every single MOBA is toxic and smite, for me, seems to be toxic mostly within arena and conquest although you will run into horrible people in other gamemodes as well.

Graphics/Sounds
The environment in smite is highly detailed and the maps such as joust also have the perk of being quite colorful and interesting in their design. The game also contains music packs which you can gain along with announcer packs which change the default ones given and are able to make your experience quite better if you get the right pack.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ Third Person MOBA
+ Good tutorials
+ 7 different normal gamemodes
+ Ultimate god pack
+ Game events
+ Actual god lore (I mean I could read up on it, but it's a nice thing to look at when in que for a match)
+ Fun to play
+ Much better community than Dota or League (in my opinion)

Cons

- Certain toxic gamemodes (gamemodes where you will almost definitely run into someone who worsens your experience)
- Achievement Glitch (if you already had a smite account and got a major portion of achievements, those achievements will NOT unlock on steam)

Final Thoughts
I love smite, I won't hide the fact that this game has caught me perfectly. I have 420 hours on record of the time of this review being written and I don't regret a single second. I've met great people who I still regularly play with and I've also met people who simply stunned me (NOT in a good way). I usually play Joust and Assault like crazy because those are the two gamemodes I started with. Now I'm trying to get into conquest, but it's a completely different way of playing when you compare Joust and Conquest. I tried League and I hated it, simply hated it. I tried Dota for awhile, but once Russians and others started yelling at me in different languages because of their own mistakes I dropped Dota too. Then finally Smite was released on steam and I bought the god pack within the first 2-3 weeks of playing and I played with some of my close friends. I left smite for a while just before season 3, but now I've come back and nearly doubled my hours since I took my extended break.

For someone to be able to write an in-depth review for this game you need around 100 hours in my personal opinion before you've actually started to truly experience the game, but for a funny and quick review a lower time is perfectly alright. You can't go in-depth, truly in-depth with a review for this game with little hours. If you have under 30 then you simply don't know practically anything about this game! Anyway, I do love this game and am glad I found a MOBA which I actually like.

TL; DR
As the funny review which made me try this game said Smite is the MOBA for people who hate MOBA's". This is a MOBA in third person where you aim all of your abilities and basic attacks
date: not just click and wait. The game contains 76 gods and 7 different normal gamemodes (not including custom/bot/ranked) at this time so there is a lot of variety for players to try things out. You will run into toxic people
hoursPlayed: but you will also most likely be able to meet good people in different gamemodes as you continue to play who will help you out

reviewText:
I never could get into MOBAs until I tried Smite, I've played Heroes of the Storm, League of Legends, and a very small amount of dota 2. The main thing that I did not like is the isometric viewpoint, as well as the click to move aspect of the traditional MOBA. Smite Fixed all of the that, when you auto attack someone it's not you just clicking on them and the attack auto hitting them no matter what, In Smite it's a skill shot that they can dodge the same principle applies to most abilities.

You start off with 5 base gods for free + another 5 on rotation.
You can buy more gods via in game credits you earn buy playing and leveling up, purchase them with real money individually with gems, or get the ultimate god pack it's $30 and gives you every god in the game as well as every feature god if you plan on playing as lot of smite it's definitely worth it. The community is amazing for a MOBA.

The main con I can think of is the servers. I live 2 hours away from LA CA and always have over 100 ping normally 120 ish.

Some tips for new players.

Buy beads! You will hear this, a lot in arena it means you should buy Purification Beads from the store it's a cheap on use item that gives you CC immunity when used. As long as you have the auto buy on it should buy them for you.

Yes there is last hitting no there is no denying.

Learn some basic VGS commands http://imagizer.imageshack.us/a/img513/9819/nww2.png

Don't worry about item builds at first. The game will auto buy a basic build for you (you can turn this off at the lobby screen before you enter a match) I recommend to play arena until you get the hang of the base gods.

The traditional MOBA map is called Conquest there is no bottom or top but long/duo lane for ADC and Support you can tell what lane this is because the towers will be farther apart and it will be the side with the gold fury, Then mid normally played by a Mage and solo/short lane normally played by a Warrior (or any god with good clear and sustain) this will always be on the side of the Fire Giant and will be either top or bottom depending if your home is the chaos or order side. Jungler will start off farming lane with solo lane (aka short lane)

If you have any questions ask in the comments and I'll try and answer as soon as I am able.

reviewText:
Smite is a third-person online MOBA game, developed by Hi-Rez Studios releasing on PC, Xbox One and due to be released on PS4. You play as the visage of a god from mythological lore and take part in different game modes against other opponents.

The major difference with Smite over other MOBAs is that you play from a third person perspective, and plays with the same sort of controls as other third person action games. The game is very arcade like in that the majority of your abilities are skillshot based rather than selecting a target and having your character auto aim for you. The game has over 70 different gods to play as, each having their own unique play style, abilities and characteristics.  There are at least seven different game modes to play in, Conquest, Arena, Joust, Assault, Siege, Clash, and Match of the Day. My favourite mode out of them all has to be arena. The matches take no longer than 20 minutes, and the players that take part in them are genuinely really nice to be around. Being a fairly novice player at Smite compared to a lot of people, I felt that Conquest, which is considered the main game mode, had a much more hostile community vibe to it with more abuse and flaming coming out of chat than any other mode I played in.  As with most MOBA type games, your characters equipment plays a key part in how well you perform, and Smite is no different. There is a wide variety of different gear to choose from, allowing you to play your character however you choose.

Smite is built using the unreal engine 3.0 technology, which provides graphics full of detail and presenting a higher graphic level than most MOBA games. The character models are all high in detail and really well animated using rag doll effects. The game‚Äôs sound effects are OK, you have to pay extra for your characters voice pack, but you still get a little bit of flavour speech here and there.

The tutorial system at the start of the game does a very good job of explaining the games main mechanics and explaining the main game mode, and I felt it got me to a sufficient skill level in order to jump into the main online game. I have been playing for about ten hours so far, and I am at that point where I can quite often find myself at the top of the kills score board, and having the least amount of deaths too. I am not saying I am absolutely amazing all of the time, but I don‚Äôt feel as if I am being carried by my team anymore and doing more good than not. This is the sort of game where practice makes all the difference ‚Äì the more you play the better you‚Äôll get.

I can honestly say I am completely hooked on Smite, and have been playing it for the past week every night after work. The matches are a perfect length before they start to drag on, and the accessibility of any of the game modes makes it really quick to find a match online. The game would be even more enjoyable if you play with friends on coms, but even from a solo perspective, I can see myself playing Smite for hours and hours.

I did have a fairly annoying technical issue which I was unable to resolve, and that is really rapid frame rate drops and freezes. I started playing the game on 4k, with all of the settings maxed out; obviously I noticed the freezing ‚Äì although it only happens when you open a menu, or a kill is announced on screen. So I dropped the resolution down to 1440p, although the same happened, reducing the resolution even more to 1080p only to find it still occurred. More so, even reducing the graphics settings did not cause the issue to disappear either, so it makes no odds whether I was playing on 4k max settings, or 1080p with low settings; the freezing happened regardless. Looking online the issue appears to be with the servers, so hopefully this can be resolved in a future patch.

Smite is one of the first MOBA games I have played for a length of time longer than 2 hours. I tend to normally stay away from this genre of game because I know how much of a time hog they can be, and I am the sort of person who will just find myself going down a rabbit hole with it, with that said, I do intend to keep on playing Smite, at least a few times a week due to how easy and quick the games are to get into. MOBA fans and even third person action skill based game fans will want to be checking this game out. The free to play model is done really well, with buying extra heroes rather than using the weekly rotation selection, and cosmetic items being the only things you can purchase.  You can pay ¬£20, 99 to unlock every single hero in the game presently as well as any future gods as well. Personally I wouldn‚Äôt purchase this as I was perfectly happy using the weekly selection of gods, but if you intend to get really stuck into the game; it may be worth picking up this pack to unlock all of the heroes.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play



----
If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

You may also be interested in checking out a PC gaming podcast, be sure to head here.

reviewText: For years my friend who has almost 2000 hours in Dota and a few hundred in LOL was telling me to start playing MOBA's with him. Eventually I gave in. And what I met was not pretty. I hated it it. It was complicated, unforgiving, and just not fun to play(especially when matches went on for an hour or more regularlly) Soon ater I tried to tell my friend why I quit. He just couldn't understand. Eventually I discovered a company called Hi-Rez and their game SMITE, which was being advertised as a MOBA. I watched the trailer and instantaniously fell in love. I adore the classics and mythology and having this put into a game was my dream. After playing the tutorial I hopped into my first match. The third person view makes the normal MOBA format feel fresh and fsat paced which is great for someone like me who has issues paying attention for a long amount of time. The graphics were beautiful, the character designs were true to their myths, and their abilities were equally so. Not only that, but the community was much more forgiving than that of DOTA or LOL. When I made mistakes people asked me if I was new before yelling at me. As time went on, I convinced my MOBA loving friend to join me, and after some This is stupid what the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• is with the camera" he fell in love as well. SMITE is now my most played game on steam and I have some 6 or 7 friends that play the game now because of me. Hi-Rez is a superb company who has made an outstanding game. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is looking for some fresh and exciting gameplay along with a lovely community who all enjoy the same game. 200/10 Would play for ever\nIn conclusion

reviewText:
All of my reviews are based around my personnal opinion, they're not swayed by a majority of people liking or disliking it.

Release: PC: March 25th 2014
Xbox One: August 19th 2015
Steam: September 8th 2015
Genre: MOBA
Developer: Hi-Rez Studios
Publisher: Hi-Rez Studios
Mode(s): Mutliplayer

TL:DR
I've never really liked MOBAs before. I always saw them as boring point & click games, but oh boy, Smite supprised me. A third person MOBA that doesn't force you to click to move? I was instantly hooked. As you might've noticed, in this game, you play as one of many different gods, all based off real mythology. This game uses similar elements to other MOBAs like League Of Legends and Dota, which are instantly recognisable to any MOBA player. Smite is one of those games where I shall continue to play it for a long time. I would also like to mention that the DLC is definitely worth it as it gives you all the gods in the game. Highly recommend this for MOBA players, and for people that don't like MOBAs.

NOTE:
All of my reviews are laid out in a particular format that fits the game.

About
Smite is a rather unique MOBA taking the third person approach whilst giving you full WASD movement of your character. A game highly inspired by mythology, allows you to play as gods based off real mythology. When you first start the game, you're only given a five gods, plus with the added ones on rotation. You can either buy them with in-game currency, with real currency, buy the Ultimate God Pack dlc or just wait for them to go on rotation, making this game far from pay2win. Smite is split into different game modes like Arena, Joust and Conquest. The game gives tutorials for the basic gameplay and how to play each gamemode. I personally found these very helpful, and was never confused at any point, either because of my experience in MOBAs or the fact that how simple they are to understand. The match is split into two teams with five gods per team, (Unless it's Joust which is split into 3v3).
In most gamemodes, the main objective is to destroy the towers, then the phoenix that guards your final objective, the titan. Depending on the gamemode, the map will have different lanes, and a jungle where you can farm xp or get bonuses to help your team. This can be crucial in modes like Conquest. You are also able to view the shop menu at your spawn where you can buy items to assist you in battle. The game gives you a choice in whether or not the game automatically buys you items, or you buy them manually.

Gameplay
When playing this game it heavily reminded me of  Super Monday Night Combat  with it's third person action style. Each character has their own skill set with four unique abilities, with the added passive ability. Each gamemode starts you off with a specific level, usually at level 3. Each time your character levels up, it gives you a skill point. The game can automatically apply the skill point to the recommended ability, but you do have the option to apply it manually. Sound like a classic LoL and Dota? It ain't. Like I mentioned earlier, the controls are set to a WASD movement. This game doesn't have as much as a learning curve compared to the other MOBA games I've played. I've actually found it quite easy to play, or at least get the jist of it.
In terms of balancing, thats up to some debate. Most I've found pretty balanced, with other gods being able to counter them easily, but there are some which are downright over-powered if you really know how to use them. Gods like Kali are a good example. This didn't always affect me. If you're in a good team, you're likely to be covered.
I also had a feq problems with matchmaking. Sometimes it can take forever to find a game which you would think would be very popular. It wouldn't do it all the time, but when it would, it's highly infuriating.
Overall I'm rather pleased that this is a MOBA with gameplay I can actually enjoy. Any other people like me who aren't fans of MOBAs are bound to be entertained by this.

Design & Graphics
Another key factor that I was very impressed with. I loved seeing the different gods and the amount of detail put into them. Same goes for the maps. Beautifully drawn and inspiring. The jungle areas, although small, have great detail too. I can say that this is helped by the cartoony style graphics.
I can run this game perfectly fine on max settings, and have a pretty stable connection to the servers. I can see the game's performance vary for different people, especially if you have a bad connection.

UI [User Interface]
If you're a MOBA player, it should be easy to find your way around things like the shop and understanding where things are and what they do. I can see this being a struggle for non MOBA players. Unless you easily understand the tutorial, (which you should do) it might take sometime getting used to the UI. It wasn't very hard for me since I've played games like Dota before, which uses a similar layout.
On the other hand, settings are easy to navigate, with nothing too difficult to find. Main menu is rather basic to navigate. Personally for me, I didn't really have a problem with the UI, but I can see how some people might.

Pros -Nice detail
-Plenty of characters
-Addicting gameplay
-A MOBA that doesn't require you to click everywhere!
-Easy to follow tutorials

Cons -A few balancing issues
-Bad matchmaking
-Relies on a good internet connection

Final Recommendation
I've had Smite in my library for quite a while now. I never had the time to play it, and when I did I just couldn't be bothered because of my past experience with MOBAs. I almost uninstalled it when I decided to give it a try. After that I couldn't stop playing. One of my first games was on conquest going against bots. Whenever I played Dota, I would always do bot matches because I would be too afraid of playing with people in case I was reported for some stupid reason, but when I gave it a go on this game, I send a message in the chat saying that this was my first match, and their words were No worries
date: just have fun" "It's only against bots
recommended: just relax and enjoy". One of my favourite communities I've ever seen. It may have a few issues
hoursPlayed: but no game is perfect. This is definitely my favourite MOBA and I highly recommend it to other people
voteText:
whether they be MOBA players or non MOBA players!

Final Verdict - 9/10.

reviewText:
Played this game since June 2012, and still play it to this day.
One of the most popular Mobas in the world. And unique in so many ways. Uses a third person camera angle that give you immersion that you can't find in other Mobas. Usable Characters are all based on Mythology, with different Pantheons being present. As of right now, there are Egyptian, Greek, Chinese, Hindu, Mayan and Norse gods in the game. All the gods have lore-friendly abilities.
Another thing that I enjoy quite a lot about this game is the lack of purchaseables that give you a competitive advantage. Take League of legends as an example. You can buy Runes with the currency, which give you an advantage against an opponent that lacks Runes. In Smite, the only thing you can buy with the free currency are gods (characters) and some skins, that are mainly re-colors of the base skin of the god. This to say that if anyone dumps a lot of cash into the game, he/she gets no advantage over someone who doesn't spend a single penny.
You get daily login rewards, and the 6th and 7th day login rewards are 15 and 35 gems, respectively. This means you can buy a regular skin if you login for 8 weeks in a row, even if you don't play a game, you can just login and collect the reward. You also get Favor (free currency) with the daily rewards, that refresh after a week. Pretty cool too.
You can also buy a pack with all the gods in the game, be it available now and in the future, with one single purchase. When I bought it, it was something like 24‚Ç¨, for all the characters in the game, forever. It's a pretty awesome deal, if you ask me, since whenever a new god is released, you automatically get it without spending currency.
Definetely recommend

reviewText:
The one complaint I always had with existing MOBAs was, that there is no point in having a strategic simulator view of the characters and indirectly clicking their walking path and attacks. SMITE solves the issue flawlessly, bringing real direct action into the MOBA genre.

The problem with SMITE for me is the matchmaking. I thought I felt, that they have a separate matching for the really low levels, but once I reached level 5 or so, which happened fast, I was matched against pre-mades of 5 with 5 solo queuers, or matched against players with hundreds of games played, as someone who plays his 20th round. This can't work. I also did have an amount of fairly balanced matches though.

Looking at past matchmaking on smite.guru makes me think, that the only matchmaking criteria is ELO. It is a huge mistake not to consider, that someone with 1000 games played and an ELO-1800 is at an entirely different level of playing than a player with 20 games played and an ELO-1800.
Maybe that would mean that the concept of ELO is flawed, or SMITEs determination process of ELO, but I just don't see it working that well. Obviously matching parties of 2 against parties of 5 can't work either.

If you can handle a hand full of frustration due to the slightly flawed matchmaking and a very beginner-unfriendly community, give SMITE a try. I would highly recommend reading up about the laning roles though, before you ever queue into Conquest" mode."

reviewText:
TL;DR You should try Smite but be wary of the saltstorm.

(Salt/Being Salty: Being angry, agitated, upset.)

Smite is a great game. I've played it since the Beta and have done the 1-30 grind as well as a few ranked games last season.

Now that this has been made clear, i'll discuss what isn't so great about it. To be blunt, the community is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. We could all agree that online video game communities are generally bad but in Smite more often than not, your game will have someone being salty towards another player for stupid reasons(anything from a teammate feeding, to someone not being able to take a joke or play along). The game has come a long way with all the visual updates and the god balance but the state of the community has just been getting worse every year. But of course, since you can just mute anyone who is fedora-neckbearding in the chat the gameplay doesn't really suffer unless you listen to their crap and let them get at you. In the end though, it's a team game, so you will have to endure some salt one way or the other.

The gameplay side of Smite is well executed and unique in the MOBA genre. The third person view and the familliarity of the gods to the common person makes the game more accessible in my opinion because not every player is interested in Lore and the bird's view in traditionnal MOBAs can be a barrier for the new player who has yet to pick up a game from the genre.

The last point that makes this game for me is the cheap god pack, in which you receive every god released as well as all future gods for like 20$USD. This method is far better than that of LoL/HotS, even though it's not nearly as good as the free DOTA 2 way of going.

Smite is at a great point in it's lifecycle for new players to join in, with the recent Steam addition and the game only being in it's second season of competitive/ranked play.

Overall, I would recommend playing Smite or simply giving it a try to see if you'd like it because it's definitely worth a shot.

reviewText:
Regardless of how you feel about MOBAs, you should be playing this game. You can go in to Smite with no prior knowledge of the genre, but as long as you know how to aim and shoot you're good to go. The game's third person view means that every skill is a skill shot, even your basic attacks. On the flip side, LoL or DoTA vets will find aspects of the game familiar yet challenging, and your past experience with MOBAs won't go to waste.

The competitive mode Conquest has the kind of rare depth that lets you pour thousands of hours into it without getting bored. If you're just looking to party up and fight, the 5v5 Arena (Deathmatch) mode is as simple and satisfying as it gets. There's also Assault (ARAM) if you can't choose which god to play.

Smite also features arguably the best deal in gaming with the Ultimate God pack. For $30 you unlock all current and future gods, meaning as of this review you've currently got 68 characters to play, and you'll own and be able to play every new god from the day they're released.

Smite is by no means P2W; all gods can be unlocked for free, and are a lot cheaper in comparison to LoL or HoTS. However, if you see yourself playing this game for any period of time, definitely consider making the small investment.

If you're into eSports, Smite has that too. With competitive leagues in NA, EU, OCE, China and Brazil/LatAm, featuring familiar names such as TSM, Fnatic, C9 and more, it's easy to get involved in the hype building up to the Smite World Championships.

I can't recommened Smite enough, and if you're even the slightest bit interested I urge you to do yourself a favour and check it out.

reviewText: I've been playing Smite for almost two years now, and I gotta say, it is my favorite MOBA ever created. Yes, I loved it more than DotA 2! It runs along the same basic rules that other MOBAs use, but it uses different game modes and an entirely different viewpoint. You see, Smite is played entirely from the third person, instead of a top down RTS-type game. This camera and the ability to fully control and aim your character's attacks lends a lot of intense gameplay to an already intense genre. Also, the fact that the characters are all gods and immortals from various faiths and mythologies lends a lot of charm to the game. Even better than that, the community in this game isn't full of entitled ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. I mean, they are definitely still there, but I've met many more nice, fair, friendly players than I have in any other MOBA. I recommend the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of this piece of gaming perfection.

reviewText:
Smite is one of my all time favourite games, and I've poured over 500 hours into this game in the past 13 months. It's unique 3rd person camera gives you a great sense of immersion, and the many game modes mean that the game can never really get stale.

There are currently 69 gods in the game, with the latest being Xing Tian. He has freaking eye nipples what's not to like!? They tend to add a new God every month, with more content patches coming in roughly every 2 weeks.

Smite offers a unique pure 5 v 5 deathmatch mode called Arena, which is set in a roman coleiseum. This is great fun and unique amongst many other MOBA games out there.

Smite is a game that is free to play but not pay to win. They give you 5 gods when you start, as well as there being a weekly rotation of 5 other gods you are free to try. If you like the gods, you can choose to purchase them with in game currency, known as favor. You earn this through simply playing matches.

I also absolutely love the game's soundtrack, with each Pantheon getting its own remix of the main theme which is played in the main lobby when a god from that pantheon is released. There are also tracks that play when the match is nearly over that really get you pumped, which overall adds to the great feel of this game.

I would reccomend this game to anyone :)

reviewText:
Smite takes a different approach to the MOBA genre than the other big names in the scene. Rather than a bird's eye view where you click to move, you have an over-the-shoulder perspective with WASD movement. Basic principles and strategies from other MOBAs will still carry over, so if you've played League or DOTA the learning curve on Smite should be a breeze. If you've played any action RPGs or MMOs (such as Wildstar Online or TERA), character movement and combat should feel familiar.


You play as gods (and demigods and monsters) from various ancient pantheons: Chinese, Egyptian, Greek, Hindu, Japanese, Mayan, Norse, and Roman.The characters are very well balanced, and it isn't until very high levels of play (high-level ranked and in the tournaments and pro scene) where some gods have prominent advantages. There are five different classes / roles for characters:

Assassin: Melee characters focused on setting up and confirming kills quickly
Guardian: Melee characters focused on initiating fights and peeling for their team; high defence and CC
Hunter: Ranged characters focused on high sustained damage
Mage: Ranged characters focused on high burst damage, crowd control and clearing minions
Warrior: Melee characters that have a good balance of damage and defence
There are a few outliers who perform differently (for example, Ao Kuang is classified as a Mage but plays like an Assassin).


Smite fits a bit more of a casual audience than LOL and DOTA. There isn't as much strategic depth in the competitive game mode, Conquest (5v5, 3 lanes) as there are in these other games. Lane pushing, rotations, jungling and itemization aren't terribly complex in Smite. This isn't to say the game isn't strategic - there is still a lot of strategy especially when it comes to teamfights and how you play certain matchups. Just that the emphasis in Smite is shifted a little away from strategy and a little towards mechanical skill (ability to hit abilities/attacks) compared to other MOBAs.

Beyond fundamental gameplay differences, Smite also has a wider range of game modes, many of which will appeal to players who just want to have some fun or focus almost entirely on the PvP aspect without the deeper strategy that comes from your typical 3-lane MOBA map. The game modes are:

Conquest: 3 lanes, 5v5, most strategy. Avg 35-50 minutes.
Arena: 5v5 Team Deathmatch. Avg 15 minutes.
Joust: 1 lane, 3v3, basic strategies. Avg 20-30 minutes.
Assault: 1 lane, 5v5, random gods, no returning to base. Avg 15-25 minutes.
Siege: 2 lanes, 4v4, siege juggernauts earned from kills and neutral boss. Avg 20-30 minutes.
Clash: 2 lanes, 5v5. basically Conquest Lite, not nearly as much strateyg. Avg 20 minutes.
Mode of the Day: Game mode that changes every day. Often is fun stuff like 80% cooldown reduction, infinite mana, everybody plays as the same god, etc.
Conquest and Joust are available in both normal and ranked modes. Ranked is only available at account level 30 (which is about 120+ hours of played time).


The business model in Smite is extremely friendly. Players will always have at least 10 gods to play at any given time. All players have the same 5 starter gods permanently unlocked: Thor (Assassin), Neith (Hunter), Ymir (Guardian), Guan Yu (Warrior) and Ra (Mage). There is also a free god rotation that will give you 5 more gods, 1 of each role. This rotation changes every week or two. You can also acquire new gods with gems (paid currency), favour (currency earned from playing and logging in frequently) or with the ultimate god pack. If you don't pay any money, you can expect to earn enough Favour to unlock an average of 1-1.5 gods per week. If you play a few hours a day you should be able to unlock 2-3 gods per week. You can also try any god for free in the Jungle Practice game mode (basically where there are target dummies and whatnot) to get a feel for them before unlocking them.

The main thing that you can spend money on (since it's not generally advised to purchase gods individually with gems/money) are skins and voice packs, although there are some smaller cosmetic things like ward skins and player avatars. Many skins are goofy or are pop-culture references. Voice packs change the sound of your in-game audio communications (VGS[smite.gamepedia.com]) to be voiced by your god rather than the default voice. Many skins will have custom (sometimes hilarious) voice packs. Purchasing a god's voice pack will also allow you to use the custom voice packs for any skins that you might own for that god.


But with every game there are some downsides, which I'll talk about now.


The servers are generally considered pretty underwhelming. Generally the servers (at least in North America, the ones I play on) are pretty stable, but every so often (few times a month) a day will come where the servers are screwy beyond belief. Additionally the base latency in the game is pretty high, and the server location for NA is questionable (all of NA has to play on servers hosted in Virginia, which is in the south-east US). While on other games and speedtest servers I will have latency of around 90-100 for servers on the east coast of US, for Smite my ping is generally 120-130. This isn't a dealbreaker for me, but it is a little disappointing.

There are also some issues with disconnects. While it's a rare occurence, sometimes people will arbitrarily be disconneted during the god picking phase, during the loading screen or mid-match. Doesn't seem like a big deal - reconnect and get back to playing right? Well sometimes, for reasons unknown, the game won't let that player reconnect no matter how many times they relog.


Another downside is performance / optimization. This is sort of a mixed bag - on one hand, it's really easy to achieve playable performance on lower end systems. Any modern(ish) computer with a dedicated video card should be able to get 60 FPS pretty easily. The downside is this doesn't translate over so well to higher end systems.

Many users (myself included) have noted reduced performance over the past 7-12 months. Even though I have a high-end system (i5-4690K + GTX 980 Ti) that can run games like GTA V at their highest settings at 90+ FPS, on Smite I have to play on medium settings to avoid dipping to 60-75 FPS in teamfights. You may not have these issues - it seems a minority of users have experienced decreased performance, and HiRez says their internal testing has yielded nothing but improvements. But it's something to take note of: if you want extremely high framerates (120-144), you're going to have to make the game look like poop to get it, most likely.

So basically, the game performs lower than it should given what it looks like. It's easy to run on lower end systems, but with the way the game looks it really seems like it should get twice the framerate that it does for the higher end systems. The game is very easily CPU limited - it only uses like 30% of my GTX 980 Ti at highest settings.


Overall, I highly recommend Smite. Very fun game, you can experience that juicy MOBA strategy and competitive setting with much more enjoyable character control. Downsides are persistent (but occasional) server issues and underwhelming (but not terrible) optimization.

reviewText:
Short Review: HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

Long Review:
Smite got recently added to the Steam Store. I have been playing smite since it was in early beta. I am very happy to see it on this store.

It is a 3rd person MOBA. With several different game modes.

MOBA aspects: 1v1 3v3 4v4 and traditional 5v5 with different maps for each game mode. Plus you can create custom matches to play with 2 to 10 players on any map.

3Rd Person: Since it is in 3rd person, it gives you a higher level of immersion than the top down MOBAs.

Balance: the game is very well balanced. Sure there are always going to be some charcters or items that seem OP, but they're not. If a newly launched character does seem OP the DEVs are quick to make adjestments and make it balance.

NO PAY TO WIN: All things that can be purchased with money are PURELY COSMETIC. The only difference is that you can buy all the characters right off the bat or unlock them over a period of time. I DID NOT BUY THE CHARCTER PACK and I was able to unlock all of them. Plus there's a RENTAL option for you to unlock them for a while for a small in game currency.

No strict character roles: Also any character can be built to almost any role. It has great flexibility.

Awesome Community: The community overall is mature and civil. Like normal human beings are. Unlike the ravage 12 year olds raised by wolves outside of human civilizations on most other MOBAs.

Reconnection:  If you get disconnected, you can reconnect back into the same match, provided the match isn't over.

Rating: 10 / 10.

reviewText:
I've played this game for over two and a half years and it‚Äôs like a drug. I keep trying to leave but I inevitably come crawling back.

Honestly, the game is great fun. But make sure you que with friends because the community is at a deadly level of toxic. Not surprising after it picked up a larger player base following its release from beta, but sometimes I have to sit back and wonder what happened to this game. Community used to be great, laid back, friendly and willing to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• around in casual matches; but now I can hardly get through one match without some guy telling me I'm playing wrong, or going off the rails because we're behind a bit. But of course this would happen, it‚Äôs a great free to play game, and with that will come the undesirables.

Gameplay is solid, the frequent patches (which can be somewhat hard to keep up with) keep the game fresh, and there's a new god release pretty often (at least once a month, give or take a week) so the Meta is changing constantly. The number of playable gods have almost doubled from when I started playing, so new content is always available. (Although in my opinion god releases are a little to frequent for my taste). Due to the consistently growing god pool, the ultimate god pack is undeniably worth it. The price hasn't changed from 3 years ago, and all current gods + all future gods for ¬£20 is a steal.

I love smite I really do, it was my game of the year last year, and it will almost always be at the top of my lists, despite all things I hate about it. It‚Äôs definitely worth playing, its F2P for Christ sake, just be careful you don't get hooked. And God help you if you queue for league...God help you.

reviewText:
One of the most unique moba experiences out there.

Review
What originally got me hooked on Smite was the mix of a moba and a 3rd person perspective. Previously having played both Dota (Warcraft 3 mod) and LoL, the concept was already familiar to me. As a big fan of World of Warcraft, where abilities feel like they have a much heavier impact due to the perspective, it felt like this game could combine those positive aspects.

The game actually managed to surpass my expectations. Smite is extremely immersive and especially when you get started, the feeling of certain abilities is just amazing. I'd like to name Thor's ultimate as an example, an ability that takes you flying above the battlefield, giving you an overview of the action and allowing you to drop down on your enemies with your hammer, letting you decide where to land - all of this in 3rd person, so expect a rollercoaster ride of fun.

The graphics are alright, the community is great, balancing isn't the best, but still better than is most other mobas I've played (original Dota, LoL, Hots), and you can spend plenty of time on this game without getting bored (around 600 hours pre-steam for me at this point).
Listed below are the points that I find especially important and how I would rate them.

Gameplay and controls 10/10
First up: It's a moba. I'm not going to explain how mobas work in general, as most people are familiar with the concept. 2 Bases, 2 teams, various lanes, minions, towers, objectives. Done. That said, Smite also has a lot of other game modes. Arena for casual fun, Assault for ARAM randomness, 3v3 Joust and 4v4 Siege for smaller groups, mode of the day of a special surprise, 1v1 Joust for those who really want to prove their individual skill.

Controls take a while to get used to, as there are so many things to consider: 4 movement keys, 4 ability keys, 2 active keys, 2 consumable keys, mouse for attacking and cancelling, VGS keys (I'll get to that later), back to base key, jump key, autowalk key. Not all of them are equally important, but they to play a major role. While you can get used to the standard setting, I recommend looking up smite superior key bindings" for some more ergonomical and intuitive key bindings I created a while ago.

Graphics 8/10
What can I say? Don't expect a modded Skyrim. Better than most other mobas
date: but that's kind of expected when we're talking about 3rd person. Smite runs on Unreal 3 and that should give you a good idea of what it'll look like. Lighting effects are nice and what really stands out are the ability and character animations (I made various slow motion videos on that just to show these more). Model quality differs between newer and older characters
recommended:
but many gradually get updated.

Music and audio 9/10
Music is more than decent
hoursPlayed: though eventually everyone grows tired of ingame music. The sound effects are great for the most part. What really stands out are the god voice packs for the VGS (see below)
voteText: there's some amazing talent in there
helpfulPercent: for example Kevin Sorbo voicing Hercules - and why yes
votesHelpful:
he does say "Disappointed!".

Communication System 9/10
Smite has the so-called VGS - Voice Guided System - that allows you to give your teammates very specific commands about what is going on with as little as 3-4 keystrokes. The system is started by pressing V (or whatever key you bind it to) and from there
votesTotal: you can see the subcontext menus.\nAs an example
votesFunny: V - R would bring you to the "Retreat" menu. Pressing V - R - R would make your character yell out "Retreat" (plus write it in chat)
commentsCount: whereas V - R - 3 would be more specific
column16: standing for "Retreat right lane".\nIn combination with the voice packs
column17: some of these can become quite gimmicky and fun
column18: while also being useful
column19: so it's a great system overall.\nThe only thing the game is missing are context-specific pings. You can ping with left or right mouse for different colored pings with a different noise
column20:
but it would be nice to ping for help in a specific place or similar.

Balancing 7/10
..is ok

column22: so my opinion on this should be taken with a grain of salt

everything is balanced around Conquest and especially 1v1 Joust is ignored a little too much (balancing the map itself that is).

Replay/Spectate System 4/10
An unusual point to talk about

column29: But that's about it. Awkward glitches in the spectate (minions walking backwards

this is probably the most annoying part of Smite.

Monetization 8/10
As usual with f2p games

reviewText:
VVGH

Smite is the first MOBA that has held my attention for more than a handfull of hours.  I've been playing off and on since beta, and according to Smite guru statistics I've clocked in over 220 hours so far which is far more than most games get from me.  The reasons I keep coming back for more?  Its third person camera, WASD controls, and the fact that you have to actually aim your skills, all of which make you feel right in the action.  With a current roster of 70 characters to play as, all of whom are modeled after gods from mythology such as Hades, Fenrir, Anubis and so on, you'll have a lot of awesome choices to play as.  Besides all of that, there are a number of pretty cool game modes from your typical 3 lane MOBA map to an arena and more.  Play and earn favor to unlock characters to play, or buy the Ultimate God Pack (includes all current and future released characters) for a reasonable price.  This game is definitely worth trying.  Try it out, this is one battleground you'll be glad you joined.

reviewText:
Before I started playing Smite I disliked everything about Mobas. I had tried them before, granted not for very long, and after a couple of hours I had just lost all interested. By then I had already uninstalled and went back to playing the same old, same old.

Smite is a Moba with a lot of fast-paced action, entertaining game modes, and well-endowed goddesses. It follows the same Jungle/ Lane combat like League of Legends does. Hi-Rez Studios were brave with the characters and designs they first implemented into the game. The character designs of the God Kali, a Hindu Goddess, landed the game in unsettled waters back in 2012, forcing the swift designs of multiple characters to be changed. Although, the original designs were similar to real life historic artworks of the God.

I look forward to playing a lot more Smite and recommend others to try out this free to play as it might change your opinion of Moba's too.

reviewText:
TPS with moba rules. Very different and yet similar to other MOBAs such as LOL or DOTA. Because of the shooter style of gameplay, it is always action packed and fast paced. You can actually feel that you are controlling gods and other powerful deities by the way the abilities look and feel.

Wide variety of characters to choose from and many of the abilities will feel familiar to you if you come from other MOBA games. Decent number of game modes and maps. Content updates are pretty regular and the content is relatively cheap when compared to LOL. You get free favor (IP from LOL) and gems (RP from LOL) just by logging in daily. The skins are really unique and many of them are are inspired by current events or have historic, cultural or mythological significance.

The game design is pretty light hearted, and the community is not nearly as toxic as other MOBAs. In my 40+ hours of playing I met maybe two people who were toxic. And those were just whiny people, easy to ignore. If you are getting burned out of MOBA or want to get into MOBA, this would be a good game to start on.

reviewText:
Quite easily one of the best games I have played in the last decade. Its pure PVP at its best. Plenty of different modes but conquest is the main one, although the others ar pretty healthy, get games within a minute at peak and off peak no more than 3 minutes.

Free 2 play done right as well, you get some gods free, and their is a weekly rotation so its the same as LoL. You buy gods with ingame currency or if you prefer you can use gems which are basically real money. I bought the god pack for ¬£20 and it was money well spent. Skins are what many people dump the ingame currency for, but as I said you can actually unlock gods with the favor you earn in game.

If you like MOBAs this is a very good take on it, and who said it needed to be top down anyway! I cannot recommend a game any higher than I do this, truly an amazing game and a lot of fun.

(also, dont worry if you are not into MOBAs either, Arena is basically a deathmatch, Joust is a 3v3 mini version of conquest, you can also do that joust as 1v1 which is nerve wracking. Siege is a sort of conquest type map but ganking is MUCH more part of the game, and your gold income is very high pushing for lots of end game.)

reviewText:
We all know about MOBAs. How there's (generally) 3 lanes split up by a jungle in-between. How there's the 5 major roles:

-Bruiser / Warrior
-Guardian / Tank
-Hunter
-Assassin (Generally the Jungler)
-Mage

Well, in SMITE, this is no different. However, SMITE adds a completely new perspective -- third person. This will throw off even the most seasoned MOBA veteran for the first few games. You will hear sounds behind you as you're running away, and you need to use those sounds to better dodge abilities. When you're getting ganked, you might hear a sound to your left or right and that's your que to bail out.

All in all, SMITE is a unique game and has it's own vibe to it. It's immensely fun to play if you put the time and effort into properly learning MOBA ettiquette.

reviewText:
Two years later. Nearly seven hundred hours played. Still going strong.
Smite is easily one of the most accessible MOBAs out there. The game's 3rd person perspective and skillshot-based gameplay make it easy to pick and and play. That's not to mention all the practice modes that can help you find your footing in this marvelous world of gods and goddesses. Yet Smite still has room for complexity. This is the kind of deep meta that makes it such a popular game to stream and that makes the Smite Pro League one of the most awe inspiring eSports shows out there today.

Yet if pro play isn't your thing, if you just want to have a good time, that's no problem at all. Smite has five regular game modes that people actually play. If you want to take a break from the big world of Conquest, Smite's classic 5v5 map, you can have plenty of choices.

You have Arena, 5v5 team fighting in a stadium surrounded by adoring spectators.

3v3 Joust, all the action of Conquest in a bite sized chunk.

Assault, pure 5v5 fighting with all random gods and no laning phase, camps, or heading back to base to heal up.

Finally, there's Siege, a unique little 4v4 map of objective-based gameplay.
But even if you somehow get bored of those five modes, there's still the Match of the Day. That's a daily, random game mode that keeps things fun. If you think buying one item at a time has gotten boring, then maybe the MotD can help you with a big pile of starting gold and infinite mana.

If you're worried about microtransactions, worry no more. The game has all kinds of built-in ways to get you the favor (earned currency) and gems (paid-for shinies) you crave. The Daily Rewards system can earn you 1,250 favor and 50 gems just for logging in and hitting the Collect button seven days in a row. Even better are free gems weekends, which net you cash just for winning games!

Gods are easy to get too. All new accounts start with five permanent free gods and five more that rotate every few weeks. With all that favor, and with enough dedication, you can get yourself all of the game's gods in a few months. If you'd rather not wait, there's also the Ultimate God Pack, which gives you all current and future gods for a one-time fee. At $30, it's easily one of the best deals in any MOBA.

So even if you have a terrible fear of everything MOBAs stand for, it's still worth giving Smite a go. I've seen everyone from Call of Duty veterans, to LoL refugees, to people who didn't like any MOBA that came before it play Smite and love it with all their heart. With an audience that big, and with a game that updates and adds new content as often as two weeks apart, what do you have to lose?

Just be a god already. C'mon!

reviewText:
I would recommend this game if it wasn't for the fact that their customer support is absolutely ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. I've gotten over 1500+ hours on this game before it came out on steam and the game itself is great and unique.
my accounts:
http://smite.guru/stats/hr/howl/summary
http://smite.guru/stats/hr/gresshoppe/summary

But, it has to be said that this game has insanely bad customer support. There has been multiple cases of false positive bans, and their usually permanent and bans by IP. When Hi-Rez is ever confronted about this, they either ignore it or unbans the player and gives them some gems if they've gotten alot of attention on social media.

Basically, tons of players have been falsely banned by opening game editing programs without even touching the game, and the bans are permanent and Hi-Rez ignores all chances of appeal by email. Open whatever injector (such as wminjector or cheat engine or just whatever) and you'll most likely get a ban without even injecting ANYTHING into the game. It's a stupid and ignorant way of dealing with cheaters. Yes it's effective, but the amount of false positives are insane.

If you ever consider to play this game, just be sure to NEVER get up in any difficulties with the support team, they won't help you, if you break a rule, expect a permanent IP-ban and no chance of appeal. Try to send support tickets and get greeted with a canned message displaying their EULA for whatever rule you broke. None of the appeals for bans are ever reviewed by a human, unless they got alot of attention by other players.

I'm fed up with this game and support team, both of my accounts that I've listed got permanently banned for opening an injector whilst having the game open (even though you can risk getting banned by not even having the game open). And I've seen multiple cases of this happening to other players.

The game itself is fairly fun, but the creators can from time to time can be absolutely horrible at what they are doing, they won't listen to anyone, unless you post it on social media and build up tons of attention ofcourse :).

reviewText:
I've been playing SMITE since closed beta and I would recommend this game to anyone who is interested in MOBA's but just can't quite get into the isometric MOBA's like DOTA 2 or League. However, SMITE does have plenty of issues that are easily fixed or balanced, which Hirez does nothing about.

Here's some pros and cons:

Pros:-Smite is good for new moba players
-The community is GENERALLY less toxic than other moba games
-The Gods (Heros, Champs) are generally very well done and-
-3rd person makes you feel more connected to your God
-I don't consider SMITE to be a FTP game. Unlike DOTA, you have to grind to unlock every God with favor you earn. However you can purchase the Ultimate God Pack (for about 30$ last I checked?), which gives you all current and future Gods forever. This is the best FTP deal you will probably ever see.


Cons:-The community gets more toxic the higher your level gets. Still not as bad as other moba's, but still toxic nontheless.
-Poorly balanced Gods. And still poorly balanced after public testing.
-Hirez nerfs and buffs Gods only because of the SPL (Pro League). Leaving ranked and casual less important and broken.
-Hirez constantly ignores broken Gods and underperforming Gods (That aren't always played in the SPL). Even after multiple community threads, comments, and even surveys.
-SMITE is free, however ... in the recent year they've been adding more and more cosmetic skins that you can ONLY get in a chest roll that will give you a 1 and ___ chance of getting the item you want to buy, regardless of the money you spend. I want to spend my money on what I WANT, not what Hirez wants.


SMITE is an overall great MOBA, even though it is still the baby in the genre. I would recommend SMITE. but be warned about the cons of this game. Hirez, like most companies, started out great but is generally getting more and more greedy by the day. And they do tend to ignore their community even more nowadays.


I would give SMITE an 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Many people are complaining about the new season 3 update. However, the Smite developers are LISTENING to the community. They have already decided to return the weekly login rewards after just two days of feedback.

Also, as a beta player who has played over 700 hours since, I think it is good we experience change in a game like this. Sure not everyone will like it, but within time you will get used to it and adapt to it, just like in other previous major patches. As shown, Hi-Rez are responsive developers, and in time they will fix the broken things that came with the new season.

Be patient. Hi-Rez is trying new innovative things, finding some ideas that work and others that fail. However, the basic fundamentals are the same, and the game is still enjoyable (for me at least).

reviewText:
I give SMITE: 9/10
This is a F2P review so scores may vary | SMITE is my most favourite MOBA EVER!. I could never get into Dota 2 or League of Legends simply because they have an overhead view which I hate the MOST. Another reason why I could never get into those type of MOBAS was because they require no skill to play (No hate but this is my opinion) where as everything in SMITE is required by skillshots which makes the game more challenging, yet more fun. It seperates the noobs from the pros.

I can proudly say, I own all the Voice packs, 2 Limited skins, 150+ skins (not recolours) and many more items. Why do I own so much of that stuff? Simply because this game is one of the most generous and fun F2P's out there. I'm so proud to see how far SMITE has come (I was a player before this came on steam).

Pros
This game is generous in every way possible. They provide gem events, which allows players to earn gems that you can buy with transactions. This method will allow players to buy cosmetics that they can't get which I think is the most helpful thing a F2P can do.
The gameplay is beyond amazing, I love everything that this game has to offer. It allows plays to time their skill shots, combine skills etc which makes the game so much fun. Yes this game is a team-based game therefore you have to work together, but there are also several other modes that you can enjoy yourself with.
The third person makes this MOBA the most unique MOBA out of all the others out there. I love the fact that having a 3rd-person MOBA makes the game full of action, and unlike LOL or Dota, you can actually see where you're god is in the team fights.
There are tons of maps and gamemodes which makes the game fun whereas in LOL there is only 1 map with 1 mode which makes it dull and boring in my opinion. I would always like to see a variety in games because then it shows that the company is innovative.
There are many gods to play aswell as god rotations which allows users to play gods for free, I mean can you get any more generous?
The prices are pretty cheap. The transaction in the game are so cheap, I mean there is a godpack that you can buy for a low price which unlocks ALL gods as well as ALL future gods. Need I say more?
The community is one of the most active gaming communities out there. The devs listen to people broadcasting their opinion on reddit and they actually change to what the community is requesting depending on the volume of posts relating to the issue. I think its good that the devs interact with the community because you feel closer to the game.
SMITE is basically a history lesson because its based on gods from real mythologies so the kit will be related to that god or goddess.
Cons
One of the worst things about this game is the fact that it sometimes has server instability. It doesn't matter how fast your internet is, sometimes you will get the occasional high ping spike which can put you off the game and mess up a kill. This is something that could be developed.
Performance can be an issue (although it hasn't been with mine). I've heard by some community memebers that the performance sometimes lags and the FPS doesn't stay consistent so be careful when chosing your settings. Even at low it can lagg for some people with high rigs.
'Forgotten Gods' don't recieve the same love as they use to when they were first released (Yes im talking about Hades, Arachne etc). It would be better if they also get the same love as other gods as their are many fans of the forgotten gods.
Hi-Rez in generall have some of the worst account security. My friend recently got hacked and she hasn't heard response from the Hi-Rez support team in over 2 weeks. Security is something that should be developed to an advanced stage by Hi-Rez studios.
I hope you have enjoyed my review of SMITE. I recommend this game to ANYONE who is bored because trust me, this game will blow your mind with the amount of free content it has.

Gameplay        Graphics        Performance        Free-to-play aspect        Enjoyment        Overall                10        9        7        10        10        9.2

reviewText:
Coming from a beta player, Smite, being an action oriented and fast paced game, is one of my favorite games in the MOBA genre. It is played from a third person perspective rather than an overtop view, clearly adding a quicker style to the game. Instead of characters like champions from League, you get to play as a fairly large (and growing) cast of Gods and Goddesses from various cultures. If you are moving to Smite from another MOBA, you'll fit right in due to the original kits of the Gods to suit anyone's play style, and similar modes. The game also handles F2P really well, having a daily rewards system that gives the game's two main currency (favor and gems) over the course of a week. Things like skins, although a bit costy in favor and gems, are completely optional. New stuff including new Gods/Godesses and skins are steadily being added to the game aswell.

The community, although sometimes bearing the occasional tryhard, is good. Most of the time, you'll get someone who is really looking to communicate and play as a team. There's also a party system in which you can get friends together and play modes with each other.

Overall, SMITE is a fun, action packed multiplayer MOBA and I suggest that you give it a go.

reviewText:
As a player of Smite since early beta, I can definitely recommend this MOBA. I find it is the best of its the best of its genre, and have had hours and hours of fun with this game and with friends. As the devs release new gods, it takes a while before they balance them, but eventually all the gods in the game get balanced, and ever single OP god can get countered in some way, whether its team composition, playstyle, or your character build. This is hands down the most fun I have had with teamwork based games. The community is good, but with this now on Steam I'm not sure how thats going to change. Its only every so often you get trolls on your team, but if you are a more advanced player, an easy fix is to play ranked matches for the most competative experience.

Most Liked Feature: Gameplay/game style. The maps are beautiful and the mechanics of movement and ability use are what make the game so distinct and fun.
Most Disliked Feature: Loki is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• OP You never see someone playing bakasura unless its random pick and they get him. This also goes for a few other underrated gods

Overall, I find this game to be one of the best games for playability, integrity, and mutltiplayer. If you are a scrub with no friends, the game can still be enjoyed. 1/10 -IGN
